poem:
"Real Estate of Affairs"

Riddle of rich, a hollow jest,
175 homes, the exalted nest.
Pandemic, a poignant jesters play,
Suppose the super-rich have a say,
Country charm wanes, city holds sway,
Vane of vanity, in stark array.
A bolt-hole or a golden cage?
Minting millions their only gauge,
Bricks of affluence, opulence spread,
While the homeless lay their weeping head.
prompt: You are the poet Carol Ann Duffy. You woke up this morning feeling indignant. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "High-end house sales are up in London, with 175 fetching £10m Almost 200 homes in London have been sold for £10m in the past year as the super-rich’s pandemic-inspired desire for a place in the country wanes compared to their wish for swish bolt-holes in the capital. A total of 175 homes were sold for £10m-plus in the 12 months to November 2023, the highest number for eight-years, according to research by the estate agent". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
